description.narrative: Promoting Kyrgyzstans youth cohesion and interaction towards Uzbekistan to address and prevent violent extremism and advance cross-border cooperation.

sector.narrative: Build resilience to shocks and crisis

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Outcome level Indicators: 1) Outcome indicator 1 a % of youth in the targeted communities who believe that diversity is an added value to their community (disaggregated data by age, sex, location) 2) Outcome indicator 1 b % of Kyrgyzstani youth that assesses positively the relations with Uzbekistan (segregated data by age, sex, location) 3) Outcome indicator 1 c Youth proposals are included and implemented in the national and subnational cooperation plans with Uzbekistan
Output level Indicators: 1) Output indicator 1.1 a #of youth with a sense of empowerment, knowledge and skills to participate in and lead collaboration initiatives, disaggregated by sex and age 2) Output indicator 1.1.b # of success stories/practices produced by the project 3) Output indicator 1.1.c. # of youth participating in cooperation and trust building initiatives with project support, disaggregated by sex and age 4) Output indicator 1.2.a. # of municipalities with increased number of interactions 5) Output indicator 1.2.b. # of items of nationals and subnational Kyrgyz-Uzbek action plans implemented 6) Output indicator 1.2.c. # of youth received legal aid

1) Baseline survey is ongoing 2) The youth forum Youth of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan are the followers of the good neighborliness was held within the plan of activities for 2018-2019 on the implementation of cross-border cooperation between the Kyrgyz Republic and the Republic of Uzbekistan. The event was held on March 11 to 12 in Osh with the participation on the young people residing in the border communities of two Republics. A three-day forum “Youth without Borders” was held in Jalal-Abad province, Kyrgyzstan, that had united more than hundred young activists from the border regions of Batken, Jalal-Abad and Osh regions of Kyrgyzstan, and Andijan, Namangan and Fergana regions of Uzbekistan. “From Ala-Too to the Black Sea” International Youth Forum held in Osh with youth from Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kazakhstan and Russia. 3) 45 (from 14 till 35 years old, among them: 16 young women and 29 young men) received primary legal aid provided by the students of legal clinics in 9 pilot municipalities. Information will be updated according to the results of community – based lawyers starting to work in September 2019 in 9 pilot municipalities.
During the inception phase, the work plan of the project has been developed based on the needs assessment of young men and women in pilot border municipalities, further agreed with the National counterparts through the MoFA (the report on situation analyses is attached). UNICEF and UNFPA had a joint call for NGO selection, went through the joint procedure, however, as a result have identified different NGOs for cooperation within this project. Based on the consultation meetings with more than 1000 representatives of the local authorities, active youth and women nine municipalities in three provinces have been identified as target locations, further agreed with the province administrations and MoFA. On March 11-12, 2019 RUNOs jointly with the State Agency on Youth, Physical Culture and Sports organized Kyrgyz – Uzbek forum with participation of youth and local authorities from Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan where the project was officially launched and presented to the partners. In April, 2019 the project team has presented the main components of the project and receive recommendations of local community representatives on the interventioned planned within the project, timeline, activities are discussed and agreed. In May 2019 UNDP team organized consultations and focus group discussions with 347 people. UNICEF and UNFPA has identified villages and schools for further work with youth
In order to address young peoples needs to channel their complaints and grievances linked with the quality of the services provided by the local providers (including Ombudsmans office, prosecution office, territorial divisions of the State Registry Service,etc), the project established Community service centers. Those centers are based in pilot municipalities and will allow reinforcing (strengthen) capacity of the local municipal service providers and to support them in the delivery of free consultative legal aid imposed by the legislation. The official opening ceremony of the service centers is planned at the beginning of 2020. The legal awareness-raising activities within the project intend not only to visualize the demand for legal assistance but also to shift the way youth approach conflict resolution, placing justice and municipal institutions as the main source of information, above the non-formal environments. Thus, Law school for 646 school students aimed at increasing legal awareness and media literacy allowed to improve their knowledge in respective areas.
The Youth-to-Youth approach in the provision of consultative legal aid by young representatives of legal clinics to young people living in pilot municipalities allowed to reach 141 young people and provide primary legal aid. This solution is sustainability oriented as they will continue to collaborate after the project ends. Two young men were employed in local municipalities after the end of the internships. This approach empowered local stakeholders (legal clinics, municipalities, universities) to see young students from law faculties as active and positive actors contributing to the development of the border communities. Within the conference held on September 26 in Osh, in Kyrgyz-Uzbek University the needs to simplify regulations for foreign students arriving from Uzbekistan were emphasized.
The project is supporting the dialogue between young people of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan as part of the bilateral national plan of the State Agency on youth, physical culture and sports on cooperation with Uzbekistan. The youth forum conducted in March 2019 with participation of Uzbek delegation where more than 100 young people from three bordering provinces of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan have discussed the partnership perspectives and presented their ideas that are to be supported by the national counterparts of both countries in the future. There were groups formed by oblasts bordering with each other and the recommendations on further cooperation developed. Out of those suggested activities between Kyrgyz and Uzbek youth, three were included into the plan within current project to be implemented together with the national counterparts and youth of three provinces of Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan (the detailed recommendations of the groups and the resolution of the forum is attached to the report).
The National Government partners have cooperation plans with Uzbekistan. Youth Forum where the project has been launched as part of the cooperation plan of the State Agency on Youth, Physical Culture and Sports of Kyrgyzstan. Several National Partners were involved into activities to present existing mechanisms to file a complaint and/or to address correctly their grievances including State Registry Service, Ombudsmans office, department of the work with citizens appeals under the Presidential Administration and State guaranteed free qualified legal aid Center. As the cases linked with nationality and obtaining citizenship should be addressed to the Presidential Administration, it was necessary to consider for further follow-up. 347 participants (219 women and 128 men; 174-youth) had a chance to voice their concerns through Focus group discussions, which identified a high demand for legal consultations and inefficient work of local service providers as major concerns for young people from the pilot municipalities. Around 299 young men and women received primary legal aid(legal issues faced by young people effectively identified and referred to competent authorities) provided by community -based lawyers. The guide was developed as a working tool, containing the most relevant information, including the main principles of legal aid according to international standards and national legislation. Key points on child-friendly legal aid as well as information on where to address the victims of violence with the nearest crisis centers addresses as advised by the UNDP Gender Team. The UNDP approach is that social inclusion is indicated by access to public services, justice and complaint mechanisms, which is entailing better trust and bringing to social cohesion.The project doesnt simply focus on a particular type of intervention. Interventions are ranged from legal awareness activities among youth, training for service providers on the “single-window” principled service, capacity building trainings for law enforcement and youth on the rights of the youth at the pretrial stage which is to be organized in the end of November 2019
